description: Neuroethology is the study of how nervous systems generate natural behaviors in animals. The
nervous system interfaces an animal with its environment, determining how an animal perceives,
learns, and reacts to stimuli.  This course explores the neural mechanisms underlying
diverse behaviors - such as escape reflexes, locomotion, and communication - in a wide range of
invertebrate and vertebrate species. Lecture concepts are unpacked through laboratory
experimentation and student presentation. Prerequisites: Math 120 (or equivalent) and one of the
following: Biology 233, 247, 266, Neuroscience 234, or Psychology 238 or permission of the
